dt: {bc}to draw or direct (something, such as someone's attention) to a different object or in different directions at the same time

dt.t: refused to be {wi}distracted{/wi} from her purpose

dt: {bc}to stir up or confuse with conflicting emotions or motives

pt: {sc}puzzle{/sc} {sc}perplex{/sc} {sc}bewilder{/sc} {sc}distract{/sc} {sc}nonplus{/sc} {sc}confound{/sc} {sc}dumbfound{/sc} mean to baffle and disturb mentally. {sc}puzzle{/sc} implies existence of a problem difficult to solve.
{sc}perplex{/sc} adds a suggestion of worry and uncertainty especially about making a necessary decision.
{sc}bewilder{/sc} stresses a confusion of mind that hampers clear and decisive thinking.
{sc}distract{/sc} implies agitation or uncertainty induced by conflicting preoccupations or interests.
{sc}nonplus{/sc} implies a bafflement that makes orderly planning or deciding impossible.
{sc}confound{/sc} implies temporary mental paralysis caused by astonishment or profound abasement.
{sc}dumbfound{/sc} suggests intense but momentary confounding; often the idea of astonishment is so stressed that it becomes a near synonym of {it}astound{/it}.

pt.t: was at first too {it}dumbfounded{/it} to reply

et: Middle English, from Latin {it}distractus{/it}, past participle of {it}distrahere{/it}, literally, to draw apart, from {it}dis-{/it} + {it}trahere{/it} to draw
shortdef: to draw or direct (something, such as someone's attention) to a different object or in different directions at the same time
to stir up or confuse with conflicting emotions or motives
